column4: Seveas : You're right that sshd ignores /etc/shells, but it will use the shell value from /etc/passwd to spawn subshells for scp and sftp.
Well, you can log in, but you can't do much with a /bin/false shell, if you read me.
by default... but as with su, you can tell sshd ot use a real shell instead of false, can't you?
I thought rescue mode booted the system single-user?
yea... which prompts to you log in as root... which by default requires no password
